Kennon Lynn Ballou wrote:

>anyway, my question is this: what do you use as inputs for something 
>like the tag 
>problem? i mean 
>i guess 
>technically i could have an input which gives the bearing for each other 
>agent and then a binary input whether or not they are It. i don't really 
>like this, though, because you have to change the number of inputs based 
>on the current number of agents in the simulation. other ideas ive had 
>were to divide the circle around the agent into a discrete number of arcs 
>and then flag the inputs that have something in their field of vision ... 
>has anyone tried anything with that kind of thing?
>  
>
I seem to keep refering to this paper, but have a look at the prey 
capture problem described in "Incremental Evolution of Complex General 
Behaviour", Faustino Gomez, Risto Miikkulainen (1996). This uses a 
sensor arc like you describe, the only difference being that it is not 
egocentric - which is something which should improve things.

The URL is 
http://nn.cs.utexas.edu/pub-view.php?RECORD_KEY(Pubs)=PubID&PubID(Pubs)=35

SharpNEAT contains (C#) code for this experiment, and it's close enough 
syntactically to C++ or Java that you should be able to cut/paste the 
relevant sections of code into a C++ source file with minimal trivial 
changes. If you want download the latest zip take a look at 
PreyCaptureBase and RandomPreyCaptureEvaluator classes, you should be 
able to rip the sensor math code out of these with ease.

The latest zip is at www.cgreen.dsl.pipex.com

Also there are compiled .Net binaries in the zip, one of which is a 
preycapture simulator. To run it you will need a windows machine with 
the freely available .Net redistributable installed.

>a separate question, what is the best solution for a light-weight, drop-in 
>with as little change as possible c++ implementation of neat? hehe no 
>offense, 
>Ken, but i saw your code a few years ago - hope you cleaned it up since 
>then :) if there isn't an existing implementation that has a very clean 
>interface, are there any plans to develop one?
>
>  
>
SharpNEAT is designed with some nice clean interfaces for this sort of 
stuff, just implement the very minimal INetworkEvaluator and IExperiment 
and you're away. Unfortunately SharpNEAT isn't currently a candidate 
host for such a problem because there is not yet any support for 
co-evolving populations. The evolution algorithm is currently geared up 
only for evolving one genome at a time.

Colin.
